In this paper, we review the optoelectronic properties and applications of graphene and graphene heterostructures in recent years. Graphene is a 2D crystal with a single atomic layer thickness consisting of sp2 hybridized conjugated carbon atoms. Graphene’s unique optical and electrical properties have led to its further development in the field of nanoscale optoelectronics. Graphene has extremely high

carrier mobility and a wide range of photoelectric response characteristics in conventional semiconductor optoelectronic devices, such as silicon and GaAs. By changing the shape of a graphene structure and combining it with other nanomaterials, nano-optoelectronic devices based on graphene have greatly improved performance. Optoelectronic devices based on graphene have broad application prospects.

2. The optoelectronic properties of graphene
Graphene, as a typical two-dimensional nanometer material, has exceptional optoelectronic properties due to its unique band structure. In addition to intrinsic optoelectronic properties, the hybridization or heterostructures of other two-dimensional materials with graphene and the change in graphene’s shape and configuration give hybridized materials or heterostructures based on graphene nanostructure unique photoelectric properties.
2.1. The intrinsic optoelectronic properties of graphene
2.1.1. The energy band structure of a zero band gap The conduction and valence bands corresponding to the two sublattices of A and B in the unit cell are connected to K points at the boundary of the first Brillouin zone, which proves that graphene is a semiconductor with a zero band gap [11,12,34]. Near the Dirac point, which is at the K high symmetry point, the energy and momentum of the electrons show a linear dispersion relationship
ε( k) = vF ∣∣∣ k ∣∣∣, where k is the wave vector of the electron wave function and vF is the Fermi velocity (vF ≈ 1.0 × 106m s−1). This linear dispersion makes the effective mass of graphene’s electrons approximately equal to zero, which means that graphene’s electrons are massless Dirac fermions [17]. Fig. 2(a) shows the band structure of graphene [12].
The novel zero band gap structure of graphene distinguishes it from other two-dimensional materials, giving it excellent optical properties. The zero-band gap of the graphene nanostructure has been changed using various methods [35–39], for example, preparing graphene quantum dots of different shapes and sizes, adding substrates or forming heterogeneous structures, and doping graphene with other elements. Changing the external electric field can modify the optical response of graphene nanomaterials by adjusting the band gap.
2.1.2. Minimum quantum conductivity and super-high carrier mobility
In the vicinity of the Dirac point K, although the carrier density is zero, graphene has a minimum conductivity, which is approximately on the order of magnitude of 4e2/h. Moreover, the mobility of the carriers is almost independent of the temperature in the range of 10 K to 100 K [28,40,41]. At room temperature, when the carrier density is 1.0 × 1012 cm−2, due to the scattering effect of phonons, the upper constraint of the carriers is 2.0 × 105 cm2 V−1 s−1 and the corresponding conductivity is 1.0 × 10−6 cm, as shown in Fig. 2(b) and (c). However, the super-high carrier’s mobility of graphene has also been verified in many experiments. Dean et al. measured the carrier’s mobility of graphene based on an h-BN substrate as high as 0.8 × 105 cm2 V−1 s−1 [39].

By excitation of the photons or electrons, the collective oscillations of the electrons on the surface of a conductor are surface plasmons. When the photons and graphene’s surface plasmons are coupled, surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) form.
